name: 4-benzyl-3-thiosemicarbazide
Reason: 4-benzyl-3-thiosemicarbazide has a basic unit of benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The presence of the benzyl group (CH2C6H5) increases the molecular weight and introduces additional van der Waals interactions, contributing approximately +20°C. The thiosemicarbazide group (NNC(=S)N) has a significant impact due to the presence of the thiocarbonyl group (C=S) and the two amide-like functionalities, which can participate in hydrogen bonding. The thiocarbonyl group is a stronger electron-withdrawing group than a carbonyl, which increases the dipole moment and intermolecular forces, contributing approximately +50°C. The two amide-like functionalities can each add around +30°C due to hydrogen bonding. The total estimated increase in melting point is +100°C.
